awd_abstract_narration:
The PI is a retired university professor who will be working pro bono on the project. This award allows an undergraduate assistant to work with the PI on assembling and preparing graphical and animation illustrations for a graduate level textbook and a historical monograph on atmospheric circulation patterns. The textbook is based on his course notes that have been developed over a period of 30 years. The award also supports the publications of a series of journal articles documenting (i) trends tropical rain rate over the past 50 years, (ii) relationships between rain rate frequency and the frequency of lightning, (ii) the signature of atmospheric tides, including the possibility of a 2 weekly lunar synodic cycle in daily rainfall, and (iii) patterns of variability of tropical Pacific sea surface temperature on time scales ranging from seasons to decades. 

The books are intended to support the teaching of atmospheric dynamics in graduate and advanced undergraduate courses taken by students preparing for careers in atmospheric research and weather forecasting. The PI is already the author of a widely used textbook: Atmospheric Science: An Introductory Survey. The research focuses on the climatology of rain rate, a variable that has important implications for agriculture and flood control. It utilizes newly available data from satellite sensors and a worldwide, ground based lightning network. The projects provide training and mentoring for PhD scientists who are still at an early stage of their research careers.

por.por_cntn:
The project supported the preparation of illustrations for a textbook entitled “The Atmospheric General Circulation”, which will  soon be available for use in graduate programs throughout the world. Co-authors are David S. Battisti, Dennis L. Hartmann and David W. J. Thompson. Scheduled for delivery to the publisher in late 2021, the book contains 370 illustrations with about 1000 individual panels, most of which are based on analysis of atmospheric and oceanographic data. Many of them are new and most of the others have required substantial adaptations of the figures that have appeared in the literature to make them suitable for a textbook.The array of graphical information in the book is designed to complement existing textbooks that delve more deeply into the mathematical framework for understanding the general circulation, but contain relatively little in way of documentation of the atmospheric phenomena that the theory is directed toward explaining. At the request of the publisher, the manuscript has been reviewed by a team of nearly 30 instructors from leading research institutions around the world and nearly all of them have affirmed that it will be a valuable instructional resource and reference book. The costs of producing the publication quality graphics that will appear in the book would not have been affordable without the support of this grant.
